results.title: Art and motion
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Paul Burnford Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the relationships between movement in nature, in space-time concepts, and in abstract art forms. Shows the relationship between space and motion in the mobiles of Calder and Usher, in the paintings of Balla, Kadinsky and Van Gogh, and in the abstract film “Colour Fragments” by Elwood Decker.

results.title: Arrival of sound
results.brief_description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. Actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the ‘Talkie Terror’, but when Don Juan and The Jazz Singer debuted, there was no turning back.

constellations_primary.name: Significant sounds
constellations_primary.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

results.description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.
description_for_label: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.

results.title: Arrival of film
results.brief_description: A compilation of different scenes from the beginning of cinema.

constellations_primary.name: Film firsts
constellations_primary.description: The early days of cinema were an exciting period of experimentation, with many inventors racing to come up with their own moving-image devices.

results.description: Louis Le Prince shot the first film on a single lens camera in 1888. But before his contribution was recognised, the French inventor mysteriously disappeared and has been largely forgotten. Thomas Edison wasn’t forgotten though. After revealing his Kinetoscope in 1893, crowds lined up to watch short films through a peephole. Housed in a large cabinet, the Kinetoscope contained 50-foot loops of 35mm film that showed everything from barber shops to bodybuilding. In 1895, moving images broke free with the Lumiere Brothers’ Cinematographe, a device that could record, develop and project film onto a screen for public viewing. It even inspired the name of the new art form – cinema.
description_for_label: Louis Le Prince shot the first film on a single lens camera in 1888. But before his contribution was recognised, the French inventor mysteriously disappeared and has been largely forgotten. Thomas Edison wasn’t forgotten though. After revealing his Kinetoscope in 1893, crowds lined up to watch short films through a peephole. Housed in a large cabinet, the Kinetoscope contained 50-foot loops of 35mm film that showed everything from barber shops to bodybuilding. In 1895, moving images broke free with the Lumiere Brothers’ Cinematographe, a device that could record, develop and project film onto a screen for public viewing. It even inspired the name of the new art form – cinema.

results.title: Around Is around
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, BFI and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The second of the two 3-D films commissioned by the British Film Institute for the Festival of Britain. It photographs moving oscilloscope patterns given stereoscopic form through the control of the different left-eye and right-eye image positions.
results.description: The second of the two 3-D films commissioned by the British Film Institute for the Festival of Britain. It photographs moving oscilloscope patterns given stereoscopic form through the control of the different left-eye and right-eye image positions.

results.title: Around Australia: lure of the Flinders
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Depicts the beauty of the Flinders Range in South Australia. Tours Wilpena Pound, a great natural basin completely encircled by a massive mountain wall. Visits early settlents - Blinman, a thriving copper mining centre a century ago, and abandoned Kanyaka where mute evidence remains of pioneers’ hardships. Features a carpet of wild flowers, fossils, rugged mountain scenery and aboriginal rock carvings.

constellations_other.name: Webwurlds
constellations_other.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

results.title: Army eagles
results.creator_credit: Peter Spender and Artransa Park Studios
results.brief_description: This documentary tells of the important role aviation plays by the Army in serving the ground forces pointing out the versatility of helicopters and light aircraft.

results.title: Armidale: provincial city
results.brief_description: Armidale is 300 miles north of Sydney in a district called New England. The film shows how the city owes its prosperity to the land, and includes a sequence on the University of New England.

results.title: Arguing the Toss of a Cat
results.brief_description: This lighthearted comedy features Victor the cat who wanders around a block of flats in a Melbourne dockside suburb. Rose and William are a young couple sharing the upstairs flat. Rose is a jazz singer auditioning for an overseas tour with a famous jazz band. William draws pictures for children’s storybooks. Rose wants William to go with her but William wants to stay put. They draw comfort from Victor and use him as a sounding board for their own side of what turns into an argument. However, the other two tenants want Victor to share their problems too.
